New Records: The Dodgers became the second team ever to throw a nine-inning shutout using at least eight pitchers.
Key Match Events: Ryan Brasier, Anthony Banda, Michael Kopech, Alex Vesia, Evan Phillips, Daniel Hudson, Blake Treinen, and Landon Knack combined for a shutout victory over the Padres in Game 4.
Will Smith hit a 432-foot two-run homer to center field, the longest home run of this postseason.
Gavin Lux hit a three-run homer.
The Dodgers shut out the Padres 8-0 in Game 4.
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers decided to have a bullpen game in Game 4 due to their decimated rotation and wounded lineup.
The team initially placed Freddie Freeman in the lineup, then scratched him less than two hours before first pitch.
Miguel Rojas was also unavailable due to a tear near his groin.
Post-Match Reflections: Dodgers manager Dave Roberts expressed pride in his team's response to adversity and their ability to 'go through what they've been through and respond the way they have really makes me excited about Game 5.'
Will Smith praised the Dodgers' relievers, saying 'they were all fantastic -- attacking the zone, putting guys away, putting up zeroes.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Dodgers will have their two best starting pitchers, Yoshinobu Yamamoto and Jack Flaherty, lined up to start in Game 5, but also have the option for another bullpen game.
The Padres had not been shut out since July 19.
Others: The Dodgers' rotation has been decimated by season-ending injuries to Tyler Glasnow, Gavin Stone, Clayton Kershaw, and Emmet Sheehan.
